articles.headline: Planning a Financial Tuneup
articles.snippet: Take a day — or two — to wrestle with your undone fiscal tasks and clean up as many of them as possible.
articles.abstract: Take a day — or two — to wrestle with your undone fiscal tasks and clean up as many of them as possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: There comes a point in most people’s lives when the pile of undone financial tasks — the un-automated bills, the out-of-balance retirement accounts, the out-of-date budget, the under-optimized rewards programs — becomes large enough to provoke a sort of low-grade anxiety.

articles.headline: Obama Was Pushed by Drug Industry, E-Mails Suggest
articles.snippet: Newly released messages between administration officials and drug industry lobbyists underscore the compromises underlying President Obama’s effort to overhaul health care.
articles.abstract: Newly released messages between administration officials and drug industry lobbyists underscore the compromises underlying President Obama’s effort to overhaul health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After weeks of talks, drug industry lobbyists were growing nervous. To cut a deal with the White House on overhauling health care, they needed to be sure that President Obama would stop a proposal intended to bring down medicine prices.

articles.headline: Briton There at Pakistan’s Birth Stays at 94, a Living Textbook
articles.snippet: An Englishman who made Pakistan his home, and education his mission, has finally resolved to retire from the school that bears his name.
articles.abstract: An Englishman who made Pakistan his home, and education his mission, has finally resolved to retire from the school that bears his name.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHITRAL, Pakistan — During a grand gathering of tribal elders in this rugged and remote mountain district recently, one guest of honor stood out: an elderly Englishman in a suit and polished shoes, his snowy hair carefully combed, the morning newspaper folded on his lap.

articles.headline: Comcast Is Said to Be Mulling Bid for BSkyB
articles.snippet: News Corporation wanted to own the British satellite broadcaster outright but its stake has been threatened by the phone-hacking scandal at one of its newspapers.
articles.abstract: News Corporation wanted to own the British satellite broadcaster outright but its stake has been threatened by the phone-hacking scandal at one of its newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: 5:05 p.m. | Updated Comcast is exploring whether the British Sky Broadcasting Group, Britain’s largest satellite broadcaster and a lucrative pay TV asset 39 percent owned by News Corporation, could become available for purchase, according to several people briefed on the company’s strategic thinking.

articles.headline: Pressed to Take Bailout, Spain Tries to Measure Its Need
articles.snippet: Spain appears poised to seek help for its ailing banks, a long-anticipated acknowledgment of the depth of its economic crisis. The only questions might be when, and how much.
articles.abstract: Spain appears poised to seek help for its ailing banks, a long-anticipated acknowledgment of the depth of its economic crisis. The only questions might be when, and how much.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain appears poised to seek a bailout of its ailing banks, a long-anticipated acknowledgment by the government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of the depths of Spain’s economic crisis.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Paul Geitner

articles.headline: For Labor, a Fight to Lead Heats Up
articles.snippet: Delegates of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest component of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., will vote on June 21 for a new president.
articles.abstract: Delegates of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest component of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., will vote on June 21 for a new president.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest union of state and local government workers — the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees — faces another important election this month, beyond last Tuesday’s recall vote on Wisconsin’s governor, Scott Walker, who retained his job despite the union’s all-out effort to oust him.

articles.headline: Holder Directs U.S. Attorneys to Track Down Paths of Leaks
articles.snippet: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. assigned two United States attorneys to lead separate criminal inquiries into disclosures of national security secrets to the news media.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. assigned two United States attorneys to lead separate criminal inquiries into disclosures of national security secrets to the news media.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Friday assigned two United States attorneys to lead separate criminal investigations into recent disclosures to the news media of national security secrets, saying they were authorized to “follow all appropriate investigative leads within the executive and legislative branches of government.”

articles.headline: In Era of Cheap Money, Consumers Are Shut Out
articles.snippet: As interest rates have been dropping to new lows, American companies have been taking advantage of the cheap borrowing costs, but consumers have been largely left on the sidelines.
articles.abstract: As interest rates have been dropping to new lows, American companies have been taking advantage of the cheap borrowing costs, but consumers have been largely left on the sidelines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Shreve, a 57-year-old science teacher in Marysville, Wash., has watched helplessly as mortgage rates have fallen. He said that despite his stellar credit score, no bank had been willing to let him trade in his 6.35 percent 30-year mortgage because his house was now worth less than when he bought it.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Spain to Accept Rescue From Europe for Its Ailing Banks
articles.snippet: European finance ministers promised up to $125 billion in aid, which they hope will quell rising financial turmoil ahead of elections in Greece next week that could roil world markets.
articles.abstract: European finance ministers promised up to $125 billion in aid, which they hope will quell rising financial turmoil ahead of elections in Greece next week that could roil world markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Responding to increasingly urgent calls from across Europe and the United States, Spain on Saturday agreed to accept a bailout for its cash-starved banks as European finance ministers offered an aid package of up to $125 billion.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder, Nicholas Kulish and Paul Geitner

articles.headline: Nurturing a Baby and a Start-Up Business
articles.snippet: Some women are combining the dual challenges of motherhood and start-up companies — dispelling the image of the tech entrepreneur as a single, usually male, wunderkind.
articles.abstract: Some women are combining the dual challenges of motherhood and start-up companies — dispelling the image of the tech entrepreneur as a single, usually male, wunderkind.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLEDGLING companies are like sticky-fingered toddlers. You’ve got to watch them every single minute.

articles.headline: South Carolina’s Pension Push Into High-Octane Investments
articles.snippet: Shortfalls in pension plans are causing many states to scour the more exotic corners of Wall Street for investments. Just ask South Carolina.
articles.abstract: Shortfalls in pension plans are causing many states to scour the more exotic corners of Wall Street for investments. Just ask South Carolina.
articles.lead_paragraph: Columbia, S.C.

articles.headline: How Banks Could Return the Favor
articles.snippet: State and local governments looking to refinance bonds are stuck in Wall Street swap deals with high interest rates — so why not save some public money?
articles.abstract: State and local governments looking to refinance bonds are stuck in Wall Street swap deals with high interest rates — so why not save some public money?
articles.lead_paragraph: LIKE millions of homeowners, shrewd state and local governments are looking to refinance. Interest rates have hit rock bottom. So why not save some public money by replacing old debts with new ones at lower rates?

articles.headline: Forced to Early Social Security, Unemployed Pay a Steep Price
articles.snippet: The recession and its aftermath have forced many older people who are out of work to draw Social Security earlier than they had planned.
articles.abstract: The recession and its aftermath have forced many older people who are out of work to draw Social Security earlier than they had planned.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — This retirement oasis in the desert has long beckoned those who want to spin out their golden years playing golf and sitting by the pool in the arid sunshine.

articles.headline: Latino Growth Not Fully Felt at Voting Booth
articles.snippet: Latinos are not voting in numbers that fully reflect their potential strength, leaving Hispanic leaders frustrated and Democrats worried as they increase efforts to rally Latino support.
articles.abstract: Latinos are not voting in numbers that fully reflect their potential strength, leaving Hispanic leaders frustrated and Democrats worried as they increase efforts to rally Latino support.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — The nation’s rapidly growing Latino population is one of the most powerful forces working in President Obama’s favor in many of the states that will determine his contest with Mitt Romney. But Latinos are not registering or voting in numbers that fully reflect their potential strength, leaving Hispanic leaders frustrated and Democrats worried as they increase efforts to rally Latino support.

articles.headline: Assad’s Response to Syria Unrest Leaves His Own Sect Divided
articles.snippet: Some Alawites have been frustrated that security forces have not crushed the opposition, while others say President Bashar al-Assad is pushing the sect to the brink of civil war with Sunni Muslims.
articles.abstract: Some Alawites have been frustrated that security forces have not crushed the opposition, while others say President Bashar al-Assad is pushing the sect to the brink of civil war with Sunni Muslims.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After Jaber Abboud, a baker from Baniyas, Syria, first lashed out publicly at President Bashar al-Assad for failing to promote real change, his neighbors ignored it.

articles.headline: In Europe, Banks Borrowing to Stay Ahead of the Tide
articles.snippet: The intervention in Spain will do little to address a weakness common to Europe’s financial institutions: an addiction to outside loans that provide day-to-day financing.
articles.abstract: The intervention in Spain will do little to address a weakness common to Europe’s financial institutions: an addiction to outside loans that provide day-to-day financing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Europe works to prop up Spain’s wobbling banks, its leaders still face a problem that plagues the Continent’s increasingly vulnerable financial institutions — a longstanding addiction to the borrowed money that provides the day-to-day financing they need to survive.

articles.headline: Europe Dodges a Bank Crisis in Spain, but Perils Lurk
articles.snippet: With an agreement to bail out Spain’s struggling banks, Europe again avoided financial chaos, but it still faces far bigger challenges that threaten the world economy.
articles.abstract: With an agreement to bail out Spain’s struggling banks, Europe again avoided financial chaos, but it still faces far bigger challenges that threaten the world economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — With an agreement to bail out Spain’s struggling banks, Europe again avoided financial chaos in a debt crisis that is in its third year. But Europe still faces far bigger challenges that threaten the Continent and, with it, the world economy.

articles.headline: Lax Security at LinkedIn Is Laid Bare
articles.snippet: Part of the problem may be that there are few consequences for companies with a lax attitude toward data. There are no legal penalties, and customers rarely defect.
articles.abstract: Part of the problem may be that there are few consequences for companies with a lax attitude toward data. There are no legal penalties, and customers rarely defect.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — LinkedIn is a data company that did not protect its data.

articles.headline: Newspaper as Business Pulpit
articles.snippet: Douglas Manchester owns the former San Diego Union-Tribune, where he is engaging in a very personal, pro-business brand of civic boosterism.
articles.abstract: Douglas Manchester owns the former San Diego Union-Tribune, where he is engaging in a very personal, pro-business brand of civic boosterism.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a growing worry that the falling value and failing business models of many American newspapers could lead to a situation where moneyed interests buy papers and use them to prosecute a political and commercial agenda.

articles.headline: Google Outsells, but Apple Cultivates Loyalty of App Developers
articles.snippet: Apps have become vital in marketing mobile technologies to consumers, and the allegiance of app developers to Apple has helped propel the success of its devices.
articles.abstract: Apps have become vital in marketing mobile technologies to consumers, and the allegiance of app developers to Apple has helped propel the success of its devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Smartphones running Google’s Android operating system outsell iPhones more than two to one. And yet, even as Google’s system has gobbled up market share, Apple has held onto one critical advantage — the loyalty of mobile app developers.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Daytime TV’s Empty Throne After ‘Oprah’
articles.snippet: In the year since Oprah Winfrey’s reliably popular talk show went off the air, no program has emerged as a consistent ratings winner to take its place.
articles.abstract: In the year since Oprah Winfrey’s reliably popular talk show went off the air, no program has emerged as a consistent ratings winner to take its place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Predictable. For years, that is what the 4 p.m. and 5 p.m. television ratings reports were like in New York City and dozens of other cities.

articles.headline: Swedes’ Twitter Voice: Anyone, Saying (Blush) Almost Anything
articles.snippet: Under a government initiative, each week a different citizen is entrusted the country’s Twitter account, @Sweden, to post at will.
articles.abstract: Under a government initiative, each week a different citizen is entrusted the country’s Twitter account, @Sweden, to post at will.
articles.lead_paragraph: TROLLHATTAN, Sweden — Chances of embarrassment are unusually high when you are @Sweden, the nation’s official Twitter spokesperson.

articles.headline: Selling Abroad, China Eases Slump at Home
articles.snippet: China reported a surge in exports, which could ease the damage from weakness in the domestic economy, but also increase trade tensions with the West.
articles.abstract: China reported a surge in exports, which could ease the damage from weakness in the domestic economy, but also increase trade tensions with the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — With China’s domestic economy stumbling badly this spring as construction and retail sales slow, this country is unleashing a fresh surge of exports that is preserving millions of jobs in Chinese factories but could fan trade tensions with the West.

articles.headline: Candidates in Mexico Signal a New Tack in the Drug War
articles.snippet: The contenders for Mexico’s presidency have promised to shift its antidrug strategy toward reducing violence there rather than blocking the flow of drugs to the United States.
articles.abstract: The contenders for Mexico’s presidency have promised to shift its antidrug strategy toward reducing violence there rather than blocking the flow of drugs to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The top three contenders for Mexico’s presidency have all promised a major shift in the country’s drug war strategy, placing a higher priority on reducing the violence in Mexico than on using arrests and seizures to block the flow of drugs to the United States.
articles.byline: By Randal C. Archibold and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Syria’s Assads Turned to West for Glossy P.R.
articles.snippet: With help from high-priced advisers, President Bashar al-Assad and his wife tried to portray themselves as progressive, and even glamorous, in the Western news media.
articles.abstract: With help from high-priced advisers, President Bashar al-Assad and his wife tried to portray themselves as progressive, and even glamorous, in the Western news media.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some journalists, Syria has been one of the least hospitable countries in the Middle East, a place where reporters — if they can get in — are routinely harassed and threatened as they try to uncover the repression that has propped up the Assad government for decades.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Raids Target Putin’s Critics Before Protest
articles.snippet: The Kremlin raised pressure on Russia’s opposition movement on Monday, searching the homes of several of its leading figures ahead of a large demonstration in central Moscow planned for Tuesday.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin raised pressure on Russia’s opposition movement on Monday, searching the homes of several of its leading figures ahead of a large demonstration in central Moscow planned for Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Kremlin raised pressure on Russia’s opposition movement on Monday, searching the homes of several of its leading figures. The coordinated early-morning raids sent a new shudder through political circles preparing for another large demonstration in central Moscow on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Rally Fizzles After Relief About Bailout Yields to Fears
articles.snippet: Stocks in the United States and Europe fell and borrowing costs soared for some of the euro zone’s most indebted members.
articles.abstract: Stocks in the United States and Europe fell and borrowing costs soared for some of the euro zone’s most indebted members.
articles.lead_paragraph: Market enthusiasm over the Spanish bank bailout did not last even a day.
articles.byline: By Christine Hauser and David Jolly

articles.headline: Worry for Italy Quickly Replaces Relief for Spain
articles.snippet: The prime minister of Italy faces a host of problems at home that may ultimately lead investors to take aim at the too-big-to-fail, 2-trillion-euro economy.
articles.abstract: The prime minister of Italy faces a host of problems at home that may ultimately lead investors to take aim at the too-big-to-fail, 2-trillion-euro economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: VENICE — Concerns grew on Monday that Italy could be the next victim of Europe’s financial infection, leading nervous investors to sell Italian stocks and bonds and damping euphoria over a weekend deal to bail out Spain’s banks.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Elisabetta Povoledo
